result.execSummary:
The defendant John J Arvoy was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Bail Jumping-Felony, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(b).
  • Theft-Movable Property <=$2500 [Modifiers: Repeater], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.20(1)(a).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes: Court orders absolute sobriety.  No possession/consumption of any intoxicants.  No use or possession of controlled substances unless valid prescription and in original containers.

counseling as deemed appropriate
Electronic Monitoring installed before leaving jail, through JusticePoint to ensure compliance with treatment and/or work obligations.
Defendant to participate in drug and/or alcohol counseling and treatment deemed appropriate by DOC and to pay all costs of treatment.
costs paid in full with bail posted

Electronic Monitoring installed before leaving jail, thru JusticePoint, to ensure compliance with treatment and/or work obligations.  Defendant is granted privileges set forth in Wis Stats 303.08
AMENDED 2/13/2015: In order to ensure compliance with treatment obligations, provided that either (1) Defendant at his own cost would have an electronic monitoring device installed or (2) Defendant ensures that his father Joseph J. Arvoy is present at the time he leaves the jail and at the time he returns, the court grants the Defendant privileges under Wis. Stat. 303.08. The courts determination under Wis. Stat. 303.08 is based upon the requirement that the Defendant himself must satisfy either condition (1) or (2) above. The Sheriff has no obligation of any kind with respect to either condition.
